title: Tidy Tuesday 2021, Week 9
description: A Tidy Tuesday challenge about race and earnings in the US
contents:
This week’s Tidy Tuesday challenge included data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS). The data I selected included a break down of weekly earnings over time from 2010-2020 by race and gender.
Knowing that both of these factors influence how much people are paid, I created two scatterplots (one for men and one for women) of earnings over time with race indicated by point color.
What struck me looking at these graphs is the strata or layers, which seem to indicate there are groups of higher and lower earners within each race.


library (tidyverse)
library (lubridate)
library (showtext)
library (RColorBrewer)

font_add_google ("Roboto")
showtext_auto ()

# Get the Data
earn <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2021/2021-02-23/earn.csv')





d <- earn %>%
  select (sex, race, ethnic_origin, year, quarter, median_weekly_earn) %>%
mutate(date = (yq(paste(year, quarter, sep = "-")))) # change year and quarter into date format





plot <- ggplot (d %>% filter (ethnic_origin != "Hispanic or Latino" & race != "All Races" & sex != "Both Sexes"), aes (x=date, y=median_weekly_earn, color = race)) +
  geom_point(size = 1.5) +
  facet_wrap (~sex, ncol = 2)

plot + theme (text = element_text (family = "Roboto",  size = 18),
         plot.title = element_text (face = "bold", size = 24),
         legend.position = "bottom",
         legend.key = element_rect (fill = "#e3e4e1"),
         legend.background = element_rect (fill = "#e3e4e1"),
         panel.grid = element_blank (),
         panel.background = element_rect(color = "#e3e4e1", fill = "#e3e4e1"),
         plot.background = element_rect(color = "#e3e4e1", fill = "#e3e4e1"),
         axis.text.y = element_text (size = 15, hjust = 0.5),
         axis.line.x = element_line (),
         axis.line.y = element_line (),
         axis.ticks.y = element_blank (),
         axis.ticks.x = element_blank (),
         plot.margin = margin (0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, "cm")) +
  labs (title = "Earnings of US Employees by Gender and Race", 
        y = "Median Weekly Earnings in $", 
        x = " ",
        color = "Race",
        caption = "Data from US BLS | Graphic @joieprout") +
  scale_color_brewer(palette = "Dark2")






ggsave ("earnings.png")

title: Tidy Tuesday 2021, Week 7:
description: Data on Wealth and Income Over Time | Urban Institute & US Census
contents:
For this week’s Tidy Tuesday challenge we looked at data about wealth and inequality in the United States. I did a simple area plot of the median wealth of Black, Hispanic, and White families from 1989-2016. The disparity is huge! The visualization shows that while the wealth of White families increased and decreased as a function of economic changes; the wealth of Blank and Hispanic families remained low.


median_wealth_race <- race_wealth %>% 
  filter (type == "Median") %>%
  filter (year >= 1989) %>%
  filter (race != "Non-White")

## Automatically use showtext to render text
showtext_auto()

plot <- ggplot (median_wealth_race, 
        aes (x = year, 
             y = wealth_family, 
             group=race, 
             fill = race)) + 
 geom_area(color = "white") +
  labs (title = "Median Wealth of US Families by Race Over Time",
          subtitle = "In Dollars Normalized for 2016",
          caption = "Data from Urban Institute and US Census | Graphic by @joieprout",
          x = " ",
          y = " ") +
  facet_wrap (~race) +
  theme (text = element_text (family = "Montserrat", size = 22),
         plot.title = element_text (face = "bold", size = 24),
         legend.position = "none",
         panel.grid = element_blank (),
         axis.text.x = element_text (size = 14),
         axis.text.y = element_text (size = 14),
         axis.ticks.y = element_blank (),
         axis.ticks.x = element_blank (),
          panel.background = element_rect(color = "gray93", fill = "gray93"),
          plot.background = element_rect(color = "white", fill = "white"),
          strip.background = element_rect(color = "gray80", fill = "gray80"),    
          plot.margin = margin(0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, "cm"))+
  scale_y_continuous(label = comma) +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette="Dark2")

plot



ggsave ("wealthplot.pdf", width = 10, height = 6)
